_meta.description: Tool and vendor recommendations by dimension and tier
_meta.usage: Look up by dimension_id + tier to get recommended tools for that maturity level

low.context: You need to establish basic tracking infrastructure and event capture
quick_wins: Set up Google Tag Manager if not already, it's free and essential
Enable GA4 enhanced measurement (scrolls, outbound clicks, video) at no cost
Implement Meta Conversions API for better ad tracking despite iOS changes
Document your current tracking in a spreadsheet (what events, where)

recommended_tools.name: Google Tag Manager
recommended_tools.fit: Everyone, no reason not to use it
recommended_tools.note: Free. Essential. Start here.

recommended_tools.name: GA4
recommended_tools.fit: Everyone, default choice for web analytics
recommended_tools.note: Free. Has limitations but good foundation.

recommended_tools.name: Elevar
recommended_tools.fit: Shopify stores wanting better server-side tracking
recommended_tools.note: Fixes common Shopify tracking gaps. Good for $1-20M brands.

low.diy_alternative: Manually implement enhanced ecommerce tracking in GA4 via GTM. Google's documentation is comprehensive. Takes 10-20 hours for a complete implementation.

medium.context: You have basics but need to unify customer identity and handle cookie limitations
quick_wins: Implement server-side tracking for key conversion events
Set up cross-domain tracking if you have multiple domains
Create a data layer documentation for your team
Audit for tracking gaps with a tool like ObservePoint or manual QA

recommended_tools.name: Segment
recommended_tools.fit: Brands wanting unified tracking + identity resolution
recommended_tools.note: Industry standard CDP. Centralizes tracking, fans out to destinations.

recommended_tools.name: RudderStack
recommended_tools.fit: More technical teams wanting CDP on own infrastructure
recommended_tools.note: Open-source alternative to Segment. Lower cost at scale.

recommended_tools.name: Littledata
recommended_tools.fit: Shopify stores wanting server-side + GA4 improvements
recommended_tools.note: Automated Shopify tracking fixes. Good alternative to Elevar.

medium.diy_alternative: Build your own server-side tracking with Cloudflare Workers or AWS Lambda. Technical but gives full control. Open-source options like Snowplow are available.

high.context: You have strong tracking but need to maintain quality and expand capabilities
quick_wins: Implement automated tracking validation/monitoring
Build a tracking health dashboard with key QA metrics
Create runbooks for common tracking issues and fixes
Evaluate real-time streaming for activation use cases

recommended_tools.name: ObservePoint
recommended_tools.fit: Brands with significant tracking who need automated auditing
recommended_tools.note: Automated tracking validation. Catches issues before they corrupt data.

recommended_tools.name: mParticle
recommended_tools.fit: Large brands needing real-time identity resolution + activation
recommended_tools.note: Enterprise-grade CDP with real-time capabilities.

recommended_tools.name: Snowplow
recommended_tools.fit: Technical teams wanting complete data ownership
recommended_tools.note: Fully customizable event tracking. You own all the data.

high.diy_alternative: Build custom monitoring with dbt tests and alerting. Many mature brands run automated QA checks as part of their data pipelines.

low.context: You need to move beyond platform-reported metrics to understand true channel contribution
quick_wins: Calculate blended CAC weekly: Total spend / New customers (from Shopify, not platforms)
Enable GA4 data-driven attribution, it's free and better than last-click
Build a simple spreadsheet comparing platform conversions vs actual orders
Implement consistent UTM taxonomy across all campaigns

recommended_tools.name: Triple Whale
recommended_tools.fit: Shopify brands under $10M wanting simple attribution
recommended_tools.note: Shopify-native. Good starting point for DTC attribution.

recommended_tools.name: Northbeam
recommended_tools.fit: DTC brands $5-50M serious about measurement
recommended_tools.note: More sophisticated than Triple Whale. MTA + incrementality framework.

recommended_tools.name: Rockerbox
recommended_tools.fit: Omnichannel brands $20M+ with complex channel mix
recommended_tools.note: Comprehensive MTA. Better for brands with significant offline or non-Shopify revenue.

low.diy_alternative: Build a first-click vs last-click comparison in a spreadsheet. Export GA4 path data and calculate what percentage of credit shifts between models. This alone reveals the attribution problem.

medium.context: You have attribution but need validation through incrementality testing
quick_wins: Run your first geo-holdout test on your highest-spend channel
Compare platform-reported ROAS to blended ROAS (total revenue / total spend)
Calculate platform conversion overlap, how much are they all claiming the same sales?
Build a channel efficiency dashboard that tracks CAC trend over time

recommended_tools.name: Measured
recommended_tools.fit: Brands wanting rigorous incrementality measurement
recommended_tools.note: Specialized in incrementality. Run proper experiments at scale.

recommended_tools.name: Recast
recommended_tools.fit: Brands $10M+ spend wanting MMM for budget allocation
recommended_tools.note: Modern MMM. Bayesian approach with faster results than traditional MMM.

recommended_tools.name: Liftsight
recommended_tools.fit: Mid-market brands wanting incrementality without enterprise pricing
recommended_tools.note: Geo-lift and incrementality testing platform. More accessible pricing.

medium.diy_alternative: Run manual geo-holdout tests. Pick 2-3 states, pause ads for 2-3 weeks, measure sales delta vs control states. Simple but effective. Google has detailed geo-experiment guides.

high.context: You have validated attribution, now automate optimization and expand coverage
quick_wins: Set up continuous incrementality monitoring (not just periodic tests)
Build automated budget reallocation alerts based on CAC thresholds
Expand attribution to new channels as you test them
Create a measurement calibration schedule, quarterly rechecks

recommended_tools.name: Cassandra (Meta)
recommended_tools.fit: Heavy Meta spenders wanting platform-run lift studies
recommended_tools.note: Free Meta conversion lift studies. Good for validating Meta specifically.

recommended_tools.name: Nielsen Marketing Cloud
recommended_tools.fit: Large brands with $50M+ spend wanting comprehensive MMM
recommended_tools.note: Enterprise MMM with broad channel coverage. High-touch service.

recommended_tools.name: Paramark
recommended_tools.fit: Brands wanting automated budget optimization based on incrementality
recommended_tools.note: Automated budget reallocation. Combines measurement with execution.

high.diy_alternative: Build internal MMM using open-source tools (Meta's Robyn, Google's Meridian). Requires data science capability but gives full control and customization.

low.context: You need to establish regular, automated reporting to replace manual spreadsheets
quick_wins: Set up a weekly KPI email (even from GA4 scheduled reports)
Create a single 'source of truth' dashboard for key metrics
Document your metric definitions (what is a 'conversion'? what is 'CAC'?)
Eliminate one manual report this month by automating it

recommended_tools.name: Looker Studio
recommended_tools.fit: Everyone, free and connects to most sources
recommended_tools.note: Free. Good starting point. Limited for complex analysis.

recommended_tools.name: Supermetrics
recommended_tools.fit: Teams wanting to pull marketing data into Sheets/Looker Studio
recommended_tools.note: Connects marketing platforms to sheets/dashboards. Great for quick automation.

recommended_tools.name: Databox
recommended_tools.fit: Teams wanting pre-built dashboards with minimal setup
recommended_tools.note: Easy setup with pre-built templates. Good for quick wins.

low.diy_alternative: Google Sheets + Google Apps Script can automate data pulls and email reports. Free and surprisingly powerful. Many templates available online.

medium.context: You have dashboards but need better self-service and consistency
quick_wins: Create a data dictionary documenting all metrics and their definitions
Set up scheduled Slack/email alerts for key metric anomalies
Train 3-5 power users to answer their own questions in dashboards
Audit existing dashboards, remove duplicates and unused reports

recommended_tools.name: Metabase
recommended_tools.fit: Technical teams wanting free self-service BI
recommended_tools.note: Open-source BI. Self-hostable. Good balance of ease and power.

recommended_tools.name: Hex
recommended_tools.fit: Data teams wanting notebook + dashboard hybrid
recommended_tools.note: Modern analytics notebook. Great for analysis that becomes dashboards.

recommended_tools.name: Omni
recommended_tools.fit: Teams wanting Looker-like semantic layer without Looker complexity
recommended_tools.note: Modern BI with modeling layer. Good for consistent metrics.

medium.diy_alternative: Define metrics in dbt and surface them through any BI tool. This 'metrics layer' approach ensures consistency regardless of which dashboard someone uses.

high.context: You have strong reporting, now add proactive alerting and predictive insights
quick_wins: Set up anomaly detection for your top 5 KPIs
Create an 'early warning' dashboard for leading indicators
Build automated commentary for weekly reports (AI-assisted)
Implement report usage tracking, know what's actually being used

recommended_tools.name: Tableau
recommended_tools.fit: Large organizations needing comprehensive BI platform
recommended_tools.note: Enterprise standard. Strong visualization and governed analytics.

recommended_tools.name: Looker
recommended_tools.fit: Data teams wanting semantic layer + self-service
recommended_tools.note: LookML modeling layer ensures consistent metrics. Now part of Google Cloud.

recommended_tools.name: Monte Carlo
recommended_tools.fit: Data teams wanting proactive data quality monitoring
recommended_tools.note: Automated anomaly detection for data quality. Know when things break.

high.diy_alternative: Build anomaly detection with dbt tests + alerting via Slack/PagerDuty. Many teams use statistical process control (SPC) methods in SQL for custom monitoring.

low.context: You need to establish any testing capability and build the muscle
quick_wins: Run one A/B test this month on anything (email subject, CTA button)
Set up a testing backlog, a simple list of hypotheses to test
Document your first test with hypothesis, results, and learnings
Calculate required sample size for your typical tests

recommended_tools.name: Klaviyo (built-in)
recommended_tools.fit: If you use Klaviyo for email, start testing there
recommended_tools.note: Built-in A/B testing. Easy starting point for email.

recommended_tools.name: Convert
recommended_tools.fit: SMBs wanting affordable website testing
recommended_tools.note: Privacy-friendly. Good balance of features and price.

recommended_tools.name: VWO
recommended_tools.fit: Growing brands wanting comprehensive testing suite
recommended_tools.note: Full CRO suite. Testing + heatmaps + session recordings.

low.diy_alternative: Manual A/B testing: create two versions, split traffic 50/50 with UTM parameters, compare in GA4. Not ideal but proves the concept with zero investment.

medium.context: You run tests but need to scale velocity and systematize learnings
quick_wins: Create a testing calendar with planned experiments
Build a learning repository documenting all past tests
Calculate your current testing velocity (tests per month)
Identify testing coverage gaps (which areas aren't being tested?)

recommended_tools.name: Optimizely
recommended_tools.fit: Brands wanting enterprise-grade experimentation
recommended_tools.note: Industry leader. Feature flags, web, and full-stack testing.

recommended_tools.name: AB Tasty
recommended_tools.fit: Mid-market brands wanting solid testing + personalization
recommended_tools.note: Good balance of capability and complexity. Strong in Europe.

recommended_tools.name: Statsig
recommended_tools.fit: Technical teams wanting modern, developer-friendly experimentation
recommended_tools.note: Built for product teams. Feature flags + experiments. Free tier available.

medium.diy_alternative: Build internal experimentation framework with feature flags (LaunchDarkly or open-source Unleash) and statistical analysis in Python/R. Gives full control.

high.context: You have mature testing, now leverage for personalization and automation
quick_wins: Implement multi-armed bandit for at least one use case
Connect test results to downstream ML models
Build automated test analysis (statistical significance checks)
Create a meta-analysis of all past experiments for strategic insights

recommended_tools.name: LaunchDarkly
recommended_tools.fit: Engineering-led organizations wanting feature flags at scale
recommended_tools.note: Best-in-class feature flags. Foundation for sophisticated experimentation.

recommended_tools.name: Amplitude Experiment
recommended_tools.fit: Amplitude users wanting integrated experimentation
recommended_tools.note: Tight integration with Amplitude analytics. Good for product-led teams.

recommended_tools.name: Eppo
recommended_tools.fit: Data teams wanting warehouse-native experimentation
recommended_tools.note: Connects to your warehouse. Use existing data infrastructure for experiments.

high.diy_alternative: Build personalization using your own ML models deployed via feature flags. Many sophisticated teams run contextual bandits on their own infrastructure.

low.context: You need to establish basic lifecycle programs beyond batch-and-blast
quick_wins: Set up welcome series if you don't have one (3-5 emails)
Implement abandoned cart flow with 2-3 touchpoints
Create a simple win-back email for 60-90 day lapsed customers
Calculate your current repeat purchase rate as a baseline

recommended_tools.name: Klaviyo
recommended_tools.fit: DTC brands on Shopify, industry standard
recommended_tools.note: Default choice for DTC. Deep Shopify integration. Good automation.

recommended_tools.name: Postscript
recommended_tools.fit: Shopify brands wanting dedicated SMS beyond Klaviyo
recommended_tools.note: SMS-focused. Often used alongside Klaviyo for dedicated SMS.

recommended_tools.name: Drip
recommended_tools.fit: Non-Shopify ecommerce brands
recommended_tools.note: Good automation capabilities. Broader ecommerce integrations.

low.diy_alternative: Start with Klaviyo's pre-built flow templates. They're not custom, but they're better than nothing and get you started while you plan more sophisticated programs.

medium.context: You have flows but need better segmentation and lifecycle stage management
quick_wins: Implement RFM segmentation (Recency, Frequency, Monetary)
Create lifecycle stage definitions (new, active, at-risk, churned)
Build a VIP program or high-value customer treatment
Set up replenishment triggers for consumable products

recommended_tools.name: Retention.com
recommended_tools.fit: Brands wanting to identify anonymous site visitors for email
recommended_tools.note: Identify anonymous visitors. Significantly expands email capture.

recommended_tools.name: Attentive
recommended_tools.fit: Brands wanting sophisticated SMS program
recommended_tools.note: Premium SMS platform. Strong for brands investing heavily in SMS.

recommended_tools.name: Yotpo
recommended_tools.fit: Brands wanting loyalty program + reviews in one platform
recommended_tools.note: Combined loyalty, reviews, SMS. Good for consolidation.

medium.diy_alternative: Build RFM segmentation in your warehouse and sync to Klaviyo via their API. Calculate churn probability with simple rules (no purchase in X days = at-risk).

high.context: You have sophisticated lifecycle, now enable predictive and 1:1 personalization
quick_wins: Implement predictive CLV to prioritize high-potential customers
Build churn prediction model to intervene before customers leave
Create personalized product recommendations based on behavior
Set up cross-channel journey orchestration (email + SMS + site)

recommended_tools.name: Bloomreach
recommended_tools.fit: Enterprise brands wanting AI-driven personalization
recommended_tools.note: Full CDP + marketing automation. AI-driven recommendations.

recommended_tools.name: Braze
recommended_tools.fit: Multi-channel brands wanting sophisticated journey orchestration
recommended_tools.note: Enterprise engagement platform. Real-time, cross-channel.

recommended_tools.name: Ometria
recommended_tools.fit: Retailers wanting purpose-built retail CDP + marketing
recommended_tools.note: Retail-specific CDP. Predictive analytics built-in.

high.diy_alternative: Build predictive models (CLV, churn) in your data warehouse, score customers daily, and sync scores to Klaviyo for segmentation. Gives control over algorithms.

low.context: You need to establish basic data infrastructure, a warehouse and automated pipelines
quick_wins: Set up a free BigQuery or Snowflake trial
Connect 2-3 key sources with a no-code ETL tool
Create your first cross-source query (e.g., join Shopify + GA4)
Document what data you have and where it lives

recommended_tools.name: BigQuery
recommended_tools.fit: Teams starting out, generous free tier
recommended_tools.note: Google's warehouse. Free tier for small data. Easy to start.

recommended_tools.name: Fivetran
recommended_tools.fit: Teams wanting no-code, reliable data pipelines
recommended_tools.note: Market leader for managed ETL. Very reliable. Pricing scales with data.

recommended_tools.name: Airbyte
recommended_tools.fit: Technical teams wanting open-source ETL
recommended_tools.note: Open-source alternative to Fivetran. Self-host or cloud. Lower cost.

low.diy_alternative: Use Stitch (free tier) to load data into PostgreSQL (free on Supabase). Gives you a working data stack for nearly zero cost. Good for learning.

medium.context: You have infrastructure but need to improve reliability, documentation, and coverage
quick_wins: Add data quality tests (nulls, duplicates, freshness checks)
Document your data models and transformations
Set up pipeline failure alerts
Connect remaining data sources to close gaps

recommended_tools.name: dbt
recommended_tools.fit: Everyone with a warehouse, industry standard
recommended_tools.note: SQL-based transformation. Open-source core. Essential for data quality.

recommended_tools.name: Snowflake
recommended_tools.fit: Growing brands needing scalable, separated compute
recommended_tools.note: Modern warehouse. Scales well. Excellent for analytics workloads.

recommended_tools.name: Census
recommended_tools.fit: Teams wanting to sync warehouse data to operational tools
recommended_tools.note: Push data from warehouse to Klaviyo, Salesforce, etc. Closes the loop.

medium.diy_alternative: Implement dbt with built-in testing and documentation. It's free and transforms how you manage data quality. Invest time here before buying more tools.

high.context: You have solid infrastructure, extend to real-time, ML, and advanced use cases
quick_wins: Evaluate streaming for real-time use cases
Set up a feature store for ML models
Implement comprehensive data observability
Create a data product roadmap for advanced capabilities

recommended_tools.name: Databricks
recommended_tools.fit: Data science teams needing notebooks + processing + ML
recommended_tools.note: Unified analytics platform. Strong for ML workloads.

recommended_tools.name: Hightouch
recommended_tools.fit: Teams wanting comprehensive reverse ETL + audience building
recommended_tools.note: Composable CDP. Activate warehouse data everywhere.

recommended_tools.name: Materialize
recommended_tools.fit: Teams needing real-time analytics with SQL
recommended_tools.note: Streaming SQL. Real-time views that stay current.

high.diy_alternative: Build real-time capabilities with Kafka/Redpanda + streaming processors. Complex but gives complete control. Many teams start with batch and add streaming incrementally.
